prompt: A photographer becomes obsessed with the haunting eyes of a young girl he captures on film, unaware that her mother is plagued by vivid nightmares of her daughter being watched, dissected, and photographed by strangers.
ground_truth:
The girl with the purple eyes did not like having her picture taken. She scowled into the camera with alarming intensity.
“Smile,” the photographer said, flashing his own toothy grin.
Her face remained unchanged. No one had asked how she felt being cornered by a stranger, or if she wanted to smile, and scowling was her only means of protest.
The girl with the purple eyes didn’t actually have purple eyes—that’s just how they looked to her classmates. Really they were deep-blue. The purple came from them being sunken, dark underneath, like a smudged plum or bruises: the combination of inherited memory—generations and generations of purple-eyed women—and many sleepless nights spent coughing, small lungs gasping for air.
She got her lungs from her father, who had suffered from asthma as well. Growing up, he was thin, probably from the lack of oxygen, breathing in just enough to survive and nothing more. Not enough to thrive or grow or run the way that most boys do, and so he remained small and devoted himself to studying biology and later, medicine. He was different from the other men in his family, and perhaps it was his smallness that made him kind.
The purple-eyed women on her mother’s side began generations ago. Years of stored fears, doubts, holding of breath so that Dad doesn’t hear you under the bed; the acceptance that even if he doesn’t hear you, he knows exactly where you are; the truth that there is no escape. Small girls’ bodies covered in fingerprints, dealt with harshly, like overworked clay.
It’s the lack of air that makes for purple eyes, whether it be from fear, asthma, dreams of drowning, or the inherited memory of what’s mine is theirs, especially if what’s mine is feminine and soft—the remembering through mothers and mothers and mothers.
After taking her photo, the toothy man, Wes, gave her a nod. While he wished he could’ve coaxed a smile out of this last one, it had been a pretty successful day. Two hours of wrangling a pre-K class into solo photos outside on the playground without a single tantrum or tear shed was success in his book.
Wes’s standard of success had changed since his art school days. Back then he spent hours shooting smoke clouds on film, or nude men in black and white. Back then success meant he had been invited onto a shoot with some obscure creative vision or had scored a free drink at a bar, sent over by someone mysterious, attractive, older. He never could have guessed that elementary-class photos would end up paying his bills, or that he would learn how to make four-year-olds smile with his exaggerated facial expressions, almost without fail.
When he got home Wes popped a bag of ready-to-steam frozen edamame into the microwave and stared at the photo of that girl, the one with eyes so deep he felt they might fall right into her head.
Damn.
She was only four or five, with bangs that cut straight across her forehead, her hair pulled back at the nape of her neck into a loose ponytail. She wore a smocked blue cotton dress that popped against her olive skin. It was an eerie photo, and this was one of those rare moments when he looked at his work and remembered what it felt like to be an artist. Suddenly, he was glad she hadn’t smiled. This made for a much better photo. Maybe not something her parents would want to hang on the fridge, but still.
Nicole pulled up thirty minutes late, screeching to a halt in front of the school. Thirty minutes late meant she would have to retrieve Ella from the office.
“We have a three-strike system, okay?” said Ms. Smith, the school’s head of administration. She was a petite lady with a southern accent, always wearing a full face of makeup, always in heels. She was someone whom Nicole would have avoided at first glance, but two months into the school year Ms. Smith had proven to be kind, warm-hearted, and welcoming while Ella and her mom learned what it meant to attend St. Ignatius Day School.
“Don’t fret about it today. I know how hard it can be with traffic and all. It’s just a formality,” she said, handing Ella’s mom a hot-pink “tardy slip.”
Despite Ms. Smith’s reassurance, the hot-pink slip certainly felt like more than just a formality. As she strode down the hall to the office, every teacher she passed stared her down, giving her a disdainful once-over. She folded the piece of paper and shoved it into her purse.
Don’t you care about your child? Are you completely self-absorbed? Don’t you know how traumatizing it is to be forgotten? Think of how this could impact her future.
She added her own harsh words to their disapproving glances.
Quite honestly, she had forgotten Ella. Well, not forgotten entirely—she had lost track of time. She had been drifting in and out of sleep, and suddenly it was 2:55, leaving her just five minutes to make the almost thirty-minute drive to Ella’s school.
She hadn’t taken the time to put on something more “adult,” or even more “mom,” and now she walked briskly through the hallway in Ugg slippers and mismatched pajamas.
On the way home Ella and her mom stopped for Chick-fil-A, a rare indulgence that they decided they had both earned. Ella got a fried-chicken sandwich and a Sprite. She ate about half her sandwich before tucking the rest away in the pocket of the seat in front of her, saving it for later. She took a pull of Sprite through the straw and nodded the way little kids do when they are exceptionally pleased with their choice in beverage.
Ella caught her mom’s eye in the rearview mirror and scrunched up her face in a smile.
Relief swept through Nicole’s shoulders and chest. She could almost cry.
“Today a man with very white teeth took our pictures without asking,” Ella said.
“I know, hon. I told you about school pictures today. That’s why you wore your dress, remember?”
“I think I forgot,” Ella stated matter-of-factly, taking another swig of Sprite.
“That’s okay, Ella. Hey, on our way home I’m going to run into Walgreens, okay? You can stay in the car and finish your Sprite.”
Ella nodded.
Wes grabbed his gym bag from the bench by the door and threw it over his shoulder, digging around in his jacket pocket for his car keys. At thirty-three, he had promised himself that he would never fall victim to that soft, midthirties dad-bod that so many of his friends had grown into, so he worked out often and ate “clean.” Sure, dad-bods were fine for them—most of them settling into complacent, accepting relationships—but he could do better.
On his way to the gym he stopped by the Walgreens to pick up some Advil, Irish Springs body wash, and a Gatorade Zero. Out of habit he waved at the TV monitor that greeted him, and the tiny mirror image version of him on the monitor waved back.
A woman walked in just as he finished waving, and Wes caught a glimpse of her in the monitor. He was transported. Her eyes were sad, sunken, dark, purple underneath, almost like someone had taken a fist to each of them. It was the second time that day Wes had seen eyes like those. His eyes followed her to the prescription counter, until the rotating display of reading glasses blocked her from view.
That evening Wes fell asleep on the couch while watching Spencer, his favorite film about Princess Diana. His dreams began with the haunted face of Princess Di as she appeared in the film, played by Kristen Stewart, withering away under the watchful eye of the royal family. Suddenly she was joined by the purple-eyed girl and the purple-eyed woman he had seen earlier that day. The three of them followed him everywhere he went—the gym, the grocery store, the car wash—but in a strange turn of events, he realized that it was he who was following them. He caught their reflections in windows, TV screens, puddles in the street. He stalked them with his camera, like a member of the paparazzi, desperate to get the right angle, the perfect photo. They did not say anything to him or acknowledge that he was there. He followed them all the way to their house in the English countryside, and then he woke up.
Ella’s dad worked late that night, so Ella and her mom agreed to watch a few episodes of Little Bear while Ella had a breathing treatment. The mask fit over her mouth and nose with a blue elastic strap that went behind her head, like the kind they show you on an airplane “in case of a loss of cabin pressure.” By now Ella was used to the sounds and smells of albuterol being pumped into her lungs and she relaxed into her beanbag chair, watching while Little Bear scooped the moon up into his bucket of water. One hour later, Ella was showered and tucked into bed wearing her polyester blue Cinderella nightgown.
“Goodnight, Ella. Sweet dreams,” her mom said, pulling her door almost to a close.
Then Nicole crawled into her own bed, allowing her feet to stretch as far as they could down into the cool cotton sheets, allowing herself to spread starfish for a moment before turning over onto her left side into a small fetal position.
It would be a late night for Michael, which meant a less than ideal night’s sleep for her. She would be on edge until he got home. She tried waiting up and opened her copy of The House of the Spirits, a book she had reread more times than she could count. Somehow she found it comforting. Something about the stored-up generations of motherhood, the trauma manifested in physical bodies, the brokenness, but also the slow growth and healing that rolled through the Trueba and del Valle families. It made her feel hopeful. She drifted in and out of sleep. Eventually, she slipped into deep sleep, the kind filled with rhythmic breathing and vivid dreams.
She dreamed that she was wandering the hallways of a big creaky house with heavy curtains and doors. She didn’t recognize the house but seemed to know exactly where to go. She was small again and wore a white nightgown smattered with blue and pink flowers. She was looking for something.
She found her way to the kitchen and paused outside the closed door. There were voices on the other side and she could see the lights on, glowing underneath. They were cold, blue, like hospital lights, or the kind associated with an alien abduction—not like the lights of the kitchen she knew. The voices she heard sounded sterile. She didn’t want to open the door because she didn’t want anyone to see her, so she peeked through the keyhole and let out a silent scream.
Splayed out on the kitchen table was Nicole’s Ella, though in this strange world she and Ella both looked about five—not possibly mother and daughter. Ella was spread wide like a butchered animal, two men bent over her little body—men rummaging around in her abdomen, poking and prodding with long metal prongs, wringing out her insides like wet paper towels, slicing through her soft belly and cracking open her chest cavity. They whispered and laughed. They seemed to be searching for something inside her, like pearl divers slicing open oyster shells, unbothered by oyster flesh and juice.
Ella’s mom could hear every snap and squelch as the men made themselves familiar with Ella’s insides, as if the awful sounds were being broadcast over a loud speaker. Then one of the men pulled out a camera with a big flashbulb on top and started snapping pictures of Ella’s body from all different angles, contorted, bloodied, splayed open, her eyes empty and deep. Every flash lit the room like a burst of lightning, and the snap of the lens made Ella’s mom feel sick—the snap, flash, snap, flash over and over again, like a strobe light.
This was more than Nicole could bear, and she let out another scream, though this one was not silent. It was loud, desperate to be heard.
Suddenly she was awake, catching the end of her own scream, which had followed her from nightmare into consciousness. For a moment she didn’t know where she was. She was enveloped in dense, still darkness. She felt a small rustle and realized she was in Ella’s room, kneeling beside her bed. She felt her own face, wet with tears; felt her arms and shoulders, her chest, making sure she was in her adult body again.
Then she felt Ella’s arm, gently; her shoulders, her head. She was warm, small and whole, still in her Cinderella nightgown, breathing deeply. Her eyes fluttered open.
“Mom, did you have a bad dream?” Ella asked, her voice full of sleep. She stroked her mom’s head gently, the way someone might pet a wild animal or baby bird.
“Ella, I did. I had a really bad dream.”
“Do you want to get in? To help you sleep?” Ella lifted her comforter a bit, showing the wide expanse of unoccupied twin bed to her left.
“For a little bit. Just until Dad gets home.” Nicole answered, climbing into bed.

prompt: A photographer becomes obsessed with the haunting eyes of a young girl he captures on film, unaware that her mother is plagued by vivid nightmares of her daughter being watched, dissected, and photographed by strangers.
ground_truth:
The girl with the purple eyes did not like having her picture taken. She scowled into the camera with alarming intensity.
“Smile,” the photographer said, flashing his own toothy grin.
Her face remained unchanged. No one had asked how she felt being cornered by a stranger, or if she wanted to smile, and scowling was her only means of protest.
The girl with the purple eyes didn’t actually have purple eyes—that’s just how they looked to her classmates. Really they were deep-blue. The purple came from them being sunken, dark underneath, like a smudged plum or bruises: the combination of inherited memory—generations and generations of purple-eyed women—and many sleepless nights spent coughing, small lungs gasping for air.
She got her lungs from her father, who had suffered from asthma as well. Growing up, he was thin, probably from the lack of oxygen, breathing in just enough to survive and nothing more. Not enough to thrive or grow or run the way that most boys do, and so he remained small and devoted himself to studying biology and later, medicine. He was different from the other men in his family, and perhaps it was his smallness that made him kind.
The purple-eyed women on her mother’s side began generations ago. Years of stored fears, doubts, holding of breath so that Dad doesn’t hear you under the bed; the acceptance that even if he doesn’t hear you, he knows exactly where you are; the truth that there is no escape. Small girls’ bodies covered in fingerprints, dealt with harshly, like overworked clay.
It’s the lack of air that makes for purple eyes, whether it be from fear, asthma, dreams of drowning, or the inherited memory of what’s mine is theirs, especially if what’s mine is feminine and soft—the remembering through mothers and mothers and mothers.
After taking her photo, the toothy man, Wes, gave her a nod. While he wished he could’ve coaxed a smile out of this last one, it had been a pretty successful day. Two hours of wrangling a pre-K class into solo photos outside on the playground without a single tantrum or tear shed was success in his book.
Wes’s standard of success had changed since his art school days. Back then he spent hours shooting smoke clouds on film, or nude men in black and white. Back then success meant he had been invited onto a shoot with some obscure creative vision or had scored a free drink at a bar, sent over by someone mysterious, attractive, older. He never could have guessed that elementary-class photos would end up paying his bills, or that he would learn how to make four-year-olds smile with his exaggerated facial expressions, almost without fail.
When he got home Wes popped a bag of ready-to-steam frozen edamame into the microwave and stared at the photo of that girl, the one with eyes so deep he felt they might fall right into her head.
Damn.
She was only four or five, with bangs that cut straight across her forehead, her hair pulled back at the nape of her neck into a loose ponytail. She wore a smocked blue cotton dress that popped against her olive skin. It was an eerie photo, and this was one of those rare moments when he looked at his work and remembered what it felt like to be an artist. Suddenly, he was glad she hadn’t smiled. This made for a much better photo. Maybe not something her parents would want to hang on the fridge, but still.
Nicole pulled up thirty minutes late, screeching to a halt in front of the school. Thirty minutes late meant she would have to retrieve Ella from the office.
“We have a three-strike system, okay?” said Ms. Smith, the school’s head of administration. She was a petite lady with a southern accent, always wearing a full face of makeup, always in heels. She was someone whom Nicole would have avoided at first glance, but two months into the school year Ms. Smith had proven to be kind, warm-hearted, and welcoming while Ella and her mom learned what it meant to attend St. Ignatius Day School.
“Don’t fret about it today. I know how hard it can be with traffic and all. It’s just a formality,” she said, handing Ella’s mom a hot-pink “tardy slip.”
Despite Ms. Smith’s reassurance, the hot-pink slip certainly felt like more than just a formality. As she strode down the hall to the office, every teacher she passed stared her down, giving her a disdainful once-over. She folded the piece of paper and shoved it into her purse.
Don’t you care about your child? Are you completely self-absorbed? Don’t you know how traumatizing it is to be forgotten? Think of how this could impact her future.
She added her own harsh words to their disapproving glances.
Quite honestly, she had forgotten Ella. Well, not forgotten entirely—she had lost track of time. She had been drifting in and out of sleep, and suddenly it was 2:55, leaving her just five minutes to make the almost thirty-minute drive to Ella’s school.
She hadn’t taken the time to put on something more “adult,” or even more “mom,” and now she walked briskly through the hallway in Ugg slippers and mismatched pajamas.
On the way home Ella and her mom stopped for Chick-fil-A, a rare indulgence that they decided they had both earned. Ella got a fried-chicken sandwich and a Sprite. She ate about half her sandwich before tucking the rest away in the pocket of the seat in front of her, saving it for later. She took a pull of Sprite through the straw and nodded the way little kids do when they are exceptionally pleased with their choice in beverage.
Ella caught her mom’s eye in the rearview mirror and scrunched up her face in a smile.
Relief swept through Nicole’s shoulders and chest. She could almost cry.
“Today a man with very white teeth took our pictures without asking,” Ella said.
“I know, hon. I told you about school pictures today. That’s why you wore your dress, remember?”
“I think I forgot,” Ella stated matter-of-factly, taking another swig of Sprite.
“That’s okay, Ella. Hey, on our way home I’m going to run into Walgreens, okay? You can stay in the car and finish your Sprite.”
Ella nodded.
Wes grabbed his gym bag from the bench by the door and threw it over his shoulder, digging around in his jacket pocket for his car keys. At thirty-three, he had promised himself that he would never fall victim to that soft, midthirties dad-bod that so many of his friends had grown into, so he worked out often and ate “clean.” Sure, dad-bods were fine for them—most of them settling into complacent, accepting relationships—but he could do better.
On his way to the gym he stopped by the Walgreens to pick up some Advil, Irish Springs body wash, and a Gatorade Zero. Out of habit he waved at the TV monitor that greeted him, and the tiny mirror image version of him on the monitor waved back.
A woman walked in just as he finished waving, and Wes caught a glimpse of her in the monitor. He was transported. Her eyes were sad, sunken, dark, purple underneath, almost like someone had taken a fist to each of them. It was the second time that day Wes had seen eyes like those. His eyes followed her to the prescription counter, until the rotating display of reading glasses blocked her from view.
That evening Wes fell asleep on the couch while watching Spencer, his favorite film about Princess Diana. His dreams began with the haunted face of Princess Di as she appeared in the film, played by Kristen Stewart, withering away under the watchful eye of the royal family. Suddenly she was joined by the purple-eyed girl and the purple-eyed woman he had seen earlier that day. The three of them followed him everywhere he went—the gym, the grocery store, the car wash—but in a strange turn of events, he realized that it was he who was following them. He caught their reflections in windows, TV screens, puddles in the street. He stalked them with his camera, like a member of the paparazzi, desperate to get the right angle, the perfect photo. They did not say anything to him or acknowledge that he was there. He followed them all the way to their house in the English countryside, and then he woke up.
Ella’s dad worked late that night, so Ella and her mom agreed to watch a few episodes of Little Bear while Ella had a breathing treatment. The mask fit over her mouth and nose with a blue elastic strap that went behind her head, like the kind they show you on an airplane “in case of a loss of cabin pressure.” By now Ella was used to the sounds and smells of albuterol being pumped into her lungs and she relaxed into her beanbag chair, watching while Little Bear scooped the moon up into his bucket of water. One hour later, Ella was showered and tucked into bed wearing her polyester blue Cinderella nightgown.
“Goodnight, Ella. Sweet dreams,” her mom said, pulling her door almost to a close.
Then Nicole crawled into her own bed, allowing her feet to stretch as far as they could down into the cool cotton sheets, allowing herself to spread starfish for a moment before turning over onto her left side into a small fetal position.
It would be a late night for Michael, which meant a less than ideal night’s sleep for her. She would be on edge until he got home. She tried waiting up and opened her copy of The House of the Spirits, a book she had reread more times than she could count. Somehow she found it comforting. Something about the stored-up generations of motherhood, the trauma manifested in physical bodies, the brokenness, but also the slow growth and healing that rolled through the Trueba and del Valle families. It made her feel hopeful. She drifted in and out of sleep. Eventually, she slipped into deep sleep, the kind filled with rhythmic breathing and vivid dreams.
She dreamed that she was wandering the hallways of a big creaky house with heavy curtains and doors. She didn’t recognize the house but seemed to know exactly where to go. She was small again and wore a white nightgown smattered with blue and pink flowers. She was looking for something.
She found her way to the kitchen and paused outside the closed door. There were voices on the other side and she could see the lights on, glowing underneath. They were cold, blue, like hospital lights, or the kind associated with an alien abduction—not like the lights of the kitchen she knew. The voices she heard sounded sterile. She didn’t want to open the door because she didn’t want anyone to see her, so she peeked through the keyhole and let out a silent scream.
Splayed out on the kitchen table was Nicole’s Ella, though in this strange world she and Ella both looked about five—not possibly mother and daughter. Ella was spread wide like a butchered animal, two men bent over her little body—men rummaging around in her abdomen, poking and prodding with long metal prongs, wringing out her insides like wet paper towels, slicing through her soft belly and cracking open her chest cavity. They whispered and laughed. They seemed to be searching for something inside her, like pearl divers slicing open oyster shells, unbothered by oyster flesh and juice.
Ella’s mom could hear every snap and squelch as the men made themselves familiar with Ella’s insides, as if the awful sounds were being broadcast over a loud speaker. Then one of the men pulled out a camera with a big flashbulb on top and started snapping pictures of Ella’s body from all different angles, contorted, bloodied, splayed open, her eyes empty and deep. Every flash lit the room like a burst of lightning, and the snap of the lens made Ella’s mom feel sick—the snap, flash, snap, flash over and over again, like a strobe light.
This was more than Nicole could bear, and she let out another scream, though this one was not silent. It was loud, desperate to be heard.
Suddenly she was awake, catching the end of her own scream, which had followed her from nightmare into consciousness. For a moment she didn’t know where she was. She was enveloped in dense, still darkness. She felt a small rustle and realized she was in Ella’s room, kneeling beside her bed. She felt her own face, wet with tears; felt her arms and shoulders, her chest, making sure she was in her adult body again.
Then she felt Ella’s arm, gently; her shoulders, her head. She was warm, small and whole, still in her Cinderella nightgown, breathing deeply. Her eyes fluttered open.
“Mom, did you have a bad dream?” Ella asked, her voice full of sleep. She stroked her mom’s head gently, the way someone might pet a wild animal or baby bird.
“Ella, I did. I had a really bad dream.”
“Do you want to get in? To help you sleep?” Ella lifted her comforter a bit, showing the wide expanse of unoccupied twin bed to her left.
“For a little bit. Just until Dad gets home.” Nicole answered, climbing into bed.
story_a:
The first time I saw her eyes, I was crouched behind the lens of my Leica, adjusting the focus to capture the delicate interplay of light and shadow in the crowded marketplace. It was late afternoon, and the sun cast a golden hue over the scene, deepening the colors of the vendor stalls and the faces of the people drifting through the narrow aisles. I was just a visitor, passing through this small town on my way to nowhere in particular, drawn by the promise of capturing the essence of everyday life in my photographs.
Then I saw her. She stood apart from the bustling crowd, a still figure in a sea of movement. Her dark hair framed a face that seemed both ageless and ancient, and her eyes—those haunting, deep-set eyes—gazed directly into the lens as if she could see through it, into me. They were eyes that spoke of wisdom and sorrow far beyond her years, and I knew in that moment that I had to capture them.
I clicked the shutter once, twice, three times, unable to tear myself away from the intensity of her gaze. It was only when a woman, presumably her mother, hurried over and took her by the hand that I lowered my camera. The woman glanced at me briefly, her expression one of guarded suspicion, before leading the girl away. But those eyes stayed with me, burned into my memory and, more importantly, onto my film.
Back in my small rented room, I developed the photos in the makeshift darkroom I had set up in the bathroom. The image of the girl emerged slowly, the chemicals revealing the stark contrast of her pale face against the dark backdrop of the market. Her eyes, even in black and white, seemed to hold a depth that was almost supernatural. I found myself staring at the photograph long after it had dried, tracing the lines of her face with my finger, lost in the mystery of who she was and what her eyes were trying to tell me.
Days turned into weeks, and I couldn't shake the image of the girl from my mind. I returned to the marketplace every day, hoping to see her again, but she was never there. I asked around, describing her to the vendors and the regulars, but no one seemed to know who she was. It was as if she had appeared out of nowhere, a ghost haunting my thoughts and my art.
My obsession with the girl began to consume me. I spent hours each night developing and re-developing the same photograph, trying to tease out more details, to understand the story behind those eyes. I started to dream about her, vivid and unsettling dreams where she would appear in different places—standing in the corner of my room, sitting at the edge of my bed, always watching me with that unblinking gaze.
One night, as I was poring over the photograph yet again, a knock on the door startled me. I opened it to find the girl's mother standing there, her face pale and drawn, her eyes filled with a mixture of fear and desperation.
"Please," she said, her voice trembling. "You have to stop."
"Stop what?" I asked, genuinely confused.
"Taking pictures of my daughter," she replied. "You've been following us, haven't you?"
"No, I—" I began, but she cut me off.
"I can feel it," she said, her voice rising. "Every night, I see her in my dreams, watched by strangers, dissected by their eyes and their cameras. It's driving me mad. You have to stop."
Her words stunned me into silence. I had no idea that my obsession had been affecting her so deeply, that she had been experiencing the same nightmares that plagued me. I wanted to explain, to apologize, but the intensity of her emotion left me speechless.
"Please," she repeated, tears welling up in her eyes. "Let us be."
She turned and walked away before I could respond, leaving me standing in the doorway, the weight of her words heavy on my shoulders. I closed the door and returned to my darkroom, staring at the photograph of the girl one last time before tucking it away in a drawer.
I didn't go back to the marketplace after that. I packed my things and moved on, hoping to leave the haunting eyes and the nightmares behind. But even now, years later, I can still see her face in my mind, those eyes staring out at me from the depths of my memory, a reminder of the unintended consequences of my obsession.
In the years that followed, I traveled far and wide, capturing images of people and places, each photograph a testament to the world as I saw it. But no matter how many faces I photographed, none ever held the same power, the same haunting beauty, as the eyes of that young girl in the marketplace.
As time passed, I found myself returning to that small town, drawn by an inexplicable need to confront the past. The marketplace was still there, much the same as I remembered it, the same vendors selling their wares, the same vibrant energy filling the air. But the girl and her mother were nowhere to be found.
I wandered through the narrow aisles, my camera hanging heavy around my neck, feeling a strange sense of loss and longing. I had hoped that coming back here would bring some sort of closure, but instead, it only deepened the mystery. I felt like a ghost, drifting through a place that no longer held any answers.
It was late afternoon when I stumbled upon a small photography shop tucked away in a quiet corner of the marketplace. Curious, I stepped inside, the bell above the door tinkling softly. The shop was filled with old cameras and photographs, a treasure trove of memories captured on film.
As I browsed the shelves, my eyes were drawn to a photograph hanging on the wall. It was a portrait of a young girl, her dark hair framing a face that seemed both ageless and ancient, her eyes—those haunting, deep-set eyes—gazing directly into the camera. My heart skipped a beat as I realized it was the same girl I had photographed all those years ago.
I turned to the shopkeeper, an elderly man with a kind smile and a twinkle in his eye.
"Who is she?" I asked, my voice barely above a whisper.
The shopkeeper looked at the photograph and then back at me, his smile fading.
"She was my granddaughter," he said softly. "She passed away many years ago."
I felt a lump form in my throat as I processed his words. The girl, the haunting eyes, the nightmares—it all made sense now. She had been trying to tell me something, to reach out from beyond the grave, and I had been too blind to see it.
"I'm sorry," I said, my voice choked with emotion. "I didn't know."
The shopkeeper nodded, his eyes filled with a sadness that mirrored my own.
"She was special," he said. "Her eyes saw things that others couldn't. She had a gift, but it also brought her great pain."
I felt a deep sense of guilt wash over me, realizing that my obsession with her had only added to that pain. I wanted to make amends, to find some way to honor her memory, but I didn't know how.
"May I buy the photograph?" I asked, hoping that having it would bring some measure of closure.
The shopkeeper shook his head. "It's not for sale," he said gently. "But you can have it. She would have wanted you to have it."
I took the photograph from the wall, feeling its weight in my hands. It was more than just a picture; it was a connection to a past I could never fully understand, a reminder of the consequences of my actions and the haunting beauty of those eyes.
As I left the shop, I felt a strange sense of peace settle over me. The girl's eyes would always be with me, a silent witness to my journey and a testament to the power of a single moment captured on film. And in that moment, I knew that my obsession had not been in vain. It had led me to a deeper understanding of myself and the world around me, and for that, I was grateful.
I walked through the marketplace one last time, the photograph clutched tightly in my hand. The sun was setting, casting a golden hue over the scene, deepening the colors and the shadows. I raised my camera and took one final picture, capturing the essence of the place that had changed my life forever. And as I did, I felt the weight of the past lift from my shoulders, replaced by a sense of hope and possibility.
In the end, it was not the photograph of the girl that haunted me, but the lesson she had taught me: that every image, every moment, holds a story waiting to be discovered, and that sometimes, the most powerful stories are the ones that we least expect.

prompt: When the battalion who helped the Hero fight the demon king returned home, they expected gold and fame. Not all of them becoming married to the same Hero they served.
ground_truth:
I froze, as my King ordered me to be detained.
In a room in the castle, amongst high-grade furniture, and girly dresses, I just...existed.
"I...This...We...", I muttered, as I was chained to the bed, my powers sealed, awaiting my fate.
My fate of...marrying the Hero whom we fought with against the demon armies and Demon King.
Hero who assured us that we will be coming home, and be rewarded.
And this is it? The reward?
A few days later, the Hero visited me.
As soon as I saw him...coming in with two of my sisters...I roared, the huge bed creaking under my struggle.
"Whew, even when your power are sealed, Brigitte, your body is still like a dragoness'." , he smiled, as my two sisters just...nodded along.
"This is it? This is the reason The Valkyrie battalion was sent, instead of everyone?!
We prided ourselves of being chosen to accompany you, as we thought it was a proof of our dedication, hard-work and talent!
And this is the true reason? WE ALL BECOME YOUR BRIDES?!", I said.
"Yeah, but don't worry, I chose you because of your dedication, hard-work and talent...
Few women look like you, few women have your stamina and damn, few women have the temper of you Valkyries...
I knew exactly what I wanted in exchange of my services, the moment I saw one of your teams, hunt a drake.", he said.
"MONSTER!", I screamed at him, but he just nodded, as he...as he looked me up and down.
"Yep, as I thought, you have the best body...especially when you aren't in your armor, and when you don't use chest binding.", he said.
I spat at him.
"Darling!", one of my...one of the women exclaimed...as she quickly cleaned him with a handkerchief.
"You already broke them...
That's why you were hellbent in getting the Incubus blood, and the Dragon Bone Marrow.", I said.
He froze...before smirking.
"Not the leader of the Valkyries for no reason, are we now?
Damn, that was a quick conclusion...yes, these two are mere concubines in my harem, so I didn't need to wait until the wedding to show them a thing or two.
But don't worry, you will be my 2nd wife, as I will have to marry a princess to be the main one, still...you will be a legal partner of mine, be proud.", he said.
That's when I snapped.
The seal on my powers broke, as I roared with anger, my powers turning to ash everything around me.
I kicked towards his groin with enough strength to shatter a mountain...yet...he stopped it with a finger.
"Such dainty feet, and look at the flexibility of these toes...", he said, as he grabbed my barefoot foot...and threw me into the wall.
"Your generals, and you will be fun to break-in, little mares of mine.
Haha, being summoned as a Hero to this world is so fun.", he said, as he turned to leave.
"Big Sis...he is nice, and kind...", one of the women said.
"Yes...and in bed...you will come to realize that this is what we should do.", the other said, as they left.
I stood there, embedded into the wall...and cried for the first time in my life.
Not because my future, not because I lost, not because all the lives my sisters sacrificed on the battlefield...
But because I will have to watch the sisters I spilt blood with...becoming his toys...
"It would have been better for all of us to die back then...", I thought, as I tried to free myself, and start thinking of ways to avoid this...
story_a:
When the battalion who helped the Hero fight the demon king returned home, they expected gold and fame. Not all of them becoming married to the same Hero they served.
The village of Eldenwood was abuzz with anticipation. Bright banners flapped in the crisp autumn air, and the scent of freshly baked bread wafted from every open window. The villagers had prepared for weeks, eager to welcome back their brave soldiers. They’d heard tales of their heroism, and most notably, of their charismatic leader, the Hero, who had vanquished the demon king.
Captain Elara stood at the forefront, her armor gleaming in the sunlight. She had led her battalion through countless battles, her prowess second only to the Hero’s. As the battalion marched through the village gates, the townsfolk erupted in cheers, showering them with flowers and tokens of gratitude.
But amidst the celebration, there was an undercurrent of confusion. The Hero, Aric, was nowhere to be seen.
The battalion gathered in the village square, where the mayor stood ready with medals and speeches. "Where is Aric?" he asked, his voice laced with concern. Elara stepped forward, her face a mask of determination.
"Aric will be here shortly," she assured the mayor, though she knew the truth was far more complicated.
That evening, as the battalion sat around a roaring bonfire, Elara recounted the events of their final battle. Aric had wielded the enchanted sword with unparalleled skill, striking down the demon king in a blinding flash of light. But in that moment of victory, something unexpected had happened. The sword, imbued with ancient magic, had bound Aric to his battalion in a way none of them could have foreseen.
"He saved us all," Elara said, her voice softening. "But the sword’s magic didn’t just defeat the demon king. It bonded us to Aric, making us all... well, married to him."
The battalion exchanged bewildered glances, the reality of their situation sinking in. They had fought side by side, bled together, and now, they were bound by a mystical marriage.
The villagers, ever supportive, took the news in stride. They had always been a practical people, and if their Hero’s victory came with an unconventional twist, so be it. The mayor himself proposed a grand feast to celebrate the union, and preparations were set into motion.
As the days passed, Aric finally returned, his presence commanding as ever. He stood before his battalion, his expression a mix of pride and humility. "I never intended for this to happen," he began, his voice steady. "But fate has bound us together. We’ve always been a family in spirit. Now, we are one in every sense."
The battalion nodded in agreement, a sense of unity settling over them. They had faced insurmountable odds together, and this new bond was just another chapter in their shared story.
During the grand feast, Elara found herself next to Aric, the warmth of the fire reflecting in his eyes. "We’ve always been stronger together," she said, raising her goblet in a toast. "To our new life, and the adventures yet to come."
Aric smiled, clinking his goblet against hers. "To us," he echoed.
As the night wore on, the villagers danced and sang, their joy infectious. The battalion, now a family in every sense of the word, joined in the revelry, their bond unbreakable.
And so, in the village of Eldenwood, the tale of the Hero and the battalion who became one lived on. It was a story of courage, unity, and an unexpected twist of fate that bound them together forever. The battalion had returned home expecting gold and fame, but what they found was something far more precious—a family forged in the fires of battle and bound by the magic of love.
As dawn broke, casting a golden hue over the village, they knew that whatever challenges lay ahead, they would face them together, as one.
story_b:
The streets were lined with cheering crowds, banners waving in the air as the battalion marched through, their minds filled with dreams of gold and glory. Children tossed flower petals, painting the cobblestones in hues of red and yellow, while townsfolk shouted praises that echoed through the bustling kingdom. The battalion, their armor gleaming in the sunlight, marched proudly, each step resonating with the rhythm of victory. They had helped the Hero defeat the demon king, and now they anticipated their well-deserved reward.
At the grand plaza, a stage had been erected, draped in royal blue and gold. The Hero stood upon it, resplendent in their ceremonial attire, a beacon of triumph and charisma. Their smile was as wide as the kingdom's borders, their eyes sparkling with the mischief of one who had always danced to the beat of their own drum. As the battalion approached, the Hero raised a hand, and the crowd fell into a hushed anticipation.
"Today," the Hero declared, their voice carrying over the sea of expectant faces, "we celebrate not only victory but unity!" There was a collective cheer, the battalion exchanging grins, their hearts swelling with pride. They had fought bravely, shoulder to shoulder with the Hero, and now was their moment.
But as a royal decree was unrolled and read aloud, the words that followed left the battalion speechless and bewildered. "It has been decreed that each soldier who fought valiantly alongside the Hero shall now be joined in matrimony to the Hero themselves!"
A stunned silence ensued, broken only by the rustling of the decree as it was rolled back up. Marcus, the stoic leader, blinked rapidly, trying to process the announcement. Beside him, Elara, the jokester, let out a bark of laughter. "I thought we'd be getting medals, not marriage licenses!" she quipped, prompting a ripple of nervous laughter through the ranks.
The Hero, with a mischievous glint in their eye, shrugged nonchalantly. "Well, I did promise to take care of you all," they said, their grin unfaltering. "And what better way to ensure your prosperity than by sharing my own?"
Some soldiers exchanged bewildered glances, while others scratched their heads, trying to wrap their minds around this unexpected twist. It was, after all, an unconventional solution to their anticipated reward. The Hero had always been an enigma, known for their unorthodox methods and whimsical nature.
As murmurs of disbelief spread, each soldier found a shimmering ring on their finger, glowing with a soft light—a symbol of their unexpected union. The ring, enchanted and binding, was more than just a trinket; it was a magical contract that intertwined their fates with the Hero's.
As the day wore on, the battalion settled into their new roles, their barracks transformed into a shared residence with the Hero. The confusion and disbelief gradually gave way to humor and camaraderie, as they navigated their unexpected marriages. Over meals and training sessions, they joked about their predicament, finding solace in the absurdity of it all.
Marcus, ever the leader, took it upon himself to maintain order amidst the chaos, while Elara kept spirits high with her quips and laughter. The Hero, true to their word, ensured that the battalion wanted for nothing, their shared lives filled with unexpected joys and challenges.
Though their dreams of gold and fame had taken a whimsical turn, the battalion found an unexpected treasure in the bonds they formed. Their shared experience became a legend in itself, a tale of bravery, unity, and love in the most unconventional of forms.
As the days turned to weeks, the battalion embraced their fate, finding joy in their shared lives and the promise of future adventures. For in the end, they realized that perhaps this was the greatest reward of all—a life intertwined with laughter, companionship, and the unyielding spirit of the Hero who had brought them all together.

story_a:
When the battalion who helped the Hero fight the demon king returned home, they expected gold and fame. Not all of them becoming married to the same Hero they served.
The village of Eldenwood was abuzz with anticipation. Bright banners flapped in the crisp autumn air, and the scent of freshly baked bread wafted from every open window. The villagers had prepared for weeks, eager to welcome back their brave soldiers. They’d heard tales of their heroism, and most notably, of their charismatic leader, the Hero, who had vanquished the demon king.
Captain Elara stood at the forefront, her armor gleaming in the sunlight. She had led her battalion through countless battles, her prowess second only to the Hero’s. As the battalion marched through the village gates, the townsfolk erupted in cheers, showering them with flowers and tokens of gratitude.
But amidst the celebration, there was an undercurrent of confusion. The Hero, Aric, was nowhere to be seen.
The battalion gathered in the village square, where the mayor stood ready with medals and speeches. "Where is Aric?" he asked, his voice laced with concern. Elara stepped forward, her face a mask of determination.
"Aric will be here shortly," she assured the mayor, though she knew the truth was far more complicated.
That evening, as the battalion sat around a roaring bonfire, Elara recounted the events of their final battle. Aric had wielded the enchanted sword with unparalleled skill, striking down the demon king in a blinding flash of light. But in that moment of victory, something unexpected had happened. The sword, imbued with ancient magic, had bound Aric to his battalion in a way none of them could have foreseen.
"He saved us all," Elara said, her voice softening. "But the sword’s magic didn’t just defeat the demon king. It bonded us to Aric, making us all... well, married to him."
The battalion exchanged bewildered glances, the reality of their situation sinking in. They had fought side by side, bled together, and now, they were bound by a mystical marriage.
The villagers, ever supportive, took the news in stride. They had always been a practical people, and if their Hero’s victory came with an unconventional twist, so be it. The mayor himself proposed a grand feast to celebrate the union, and preparations were set into motion.
As the days passed, Aric finally returned, his presence commanding as ever. He stood before his battalion, his expression a mix of pride and humility. "I never intended for this to happen," he began, his voice steady. "But fate has bound us together. We’ve always been a family in spirit. Now, we are one in every sense."
The battalion nodded in agreement, a sense of unity settling over them. They had faced insurmountable odds together, and this new bond was just another chapter in their shared story.
During the grand feast, Elara found herself next to Aric, the warmth of the fire reflecting in his eyes. "We’ve always been stronger together," she said, raising her goblet in a toast. "To our new life, and the adventures yet to come."
Aric smiled, clinking his goblet against hers. "To us," he echoed.
As the night wore on, the villagers danced and sang, their joy infectious. The battalion, now a family in every sense of the word, joined in the revelry, their bond unbreakable.
And so, in the village of Eldenwood, the tale of the Hero and the battalion who became one lived on. It was a story of courage, unity, and an unexpected twist of fate that bound them together forever. The battalion had returned home expecting gold and fame, but what they found was something far more precious—a family forged in the fires of battle and bound by the magic of love.
As dawn broke, casting a golden hue over the village, they knew that whatever challenges lay ahead, they would face them together, as one.
story_b:
Returning from the battlefield victorious was supposed to be the pinnacle of our lives. As we marched back into town, the banners of triumph fluttering in the wind, our battalion anticipated the rewards of glory—gold, fame, and a return to the comforts of civilian life. Instead, what awaited us was a reality none had fathomed.
The town square was packed with jubilant crowds, cheering and tossing flowers as we approached. But as we stepped onto the cobblestones, a peculiar hush fell over the assembly. In the center stood the Hero, Elara, a figure of legend, draped in her usual armor with a glint of mischief in her eyes. She held a scroll aloft.
“Welcome back, brave warriors,” she called, her voice cutting through the silence. “There’s something I must share with you.”
We exchanged confused glances, the initial excitement giving way to unease. Elara unfurled the scroll, revealing an intricate tapestry of runes and sigils. “It appears,” she began, “that in our quest to defeat the Demon King, we inadvertently activated a magical contract. A rather... binding one.”
“What kind of contract?” I found myself asking, my voice betraying the skepticism I felt.
“One that has, in essence, married all of you to me,” Elara replied, her tone oddly unfazed, as if this were merely another strategic hurdle to overcome.
A wave of disbelief rippled through the battalion. “Married?” someone echoed incredulously. “We fought for glory, not for this!”
Yet as we stood there, the reality began to sink in. The magical contract was no ordinary parchment. It shimmered with an aura of undeniable truth. The realization that we were bound not just in arms but in matrimony to the Hero herself was a revelation that left us reeling.
“What do we do now?” one of the younger soldiers asked, his voice tinged with a mix of frustration and curiosity.
“We approach this with the same strategy and precision we used on the battlefield,” I suggested, echoing our battalion’s ethos. “But first, we need to understand the nature of this contract.”
Elara nodded, her composure unwavering. “I’ve already started an investigation. There’s a library on the outskirts of the town with ancient texts that might hold the answers.”
As we delved into the investigation, the battalion began piecing together the elements of the spell. The contract wasn’t a malicious trap but rather a binding of fates crafted by an ancient sorcerer who believed in unity through strength. The more we uncovered, the more we realized the potential benefits. Our bond with Elara granted us a shared strength, a mystical connection that could be harnessed for protection and prosperity.
In a series of strategic meetings, we discussed how to navigate our new lives. “We can use this bond to fortify our defenses,” Elara proposed, her leadership shining through. “Together, we can achieve more than we ever could apart.”
Slowly, the battalion’s initial resistance transformed. In our interactions with the Hero, we began to see her not just as a leader but as a partner. Elara’s presence, once a source of bewilderment, became a pillar of support. Her humor, too, softened our transition. “Well, I guess we won’t need to worry about finding dates anymore,” she quipped during one of our gatherings, drawing reluctant laughter.
Reflecting on the journey, I found myself surprisingly at ease. “I never thought victory would lead to this,” I mused, a touch of irony coloring my thoughts. “But here we are.”
As days turned to weeks, acceptance replaced frustration. Our battalion adapted, each member finding their place in this unexpected union. Some discovered the joys of civilian life, while others remained warriors at heart, using their skills in new ways. And through it all, Elara stood at the center, a constant reminder of the strange, yet fulfilling path our victory had carved.
In the end, our unexpected marriages became the foundation of a bond stronger than any we had known before—a testament to the unpredictable nature of fate and the power of unity.

prompt: Trapped in a moment of freefall aboard a malfunctioning plane, a woman locks eyes with a teenage boy in a ridiculous hat, discovering an unexpected connection as they both brace for what might be their final moments.
ground_truth:
When she checked her boarding pass, she was in the middle of the row, and there was a man in a blue suit on the aisle, who gave her a big bleached-white smile as he stood to let her past. The window seat stayed unoccupied for a while, and her hopes rose when a man with a clipboard boarded the plane, his hair gauzy with dew. But there were still people in the aisle, and one of them now stopped beside her row: a huge boy, who was trying to make space for a rucksack in the overhead bin. His belly was right there—she could see it as his green shirt parted company with the belt of his jeans. The rucksack did not fit, so he clasped it to his chest as he turned sideways to squeeze past her and into the window seat. He was wearing a Peruvian hat in brown-and-white wool with a design of llamas and a flap over each ear, and there were tassels dangling from the flaps down to his collar line. A teen-ager. Ninety per cent muscle, thirty per cent puppy fat; he might have another few inches still to go. Once he was seated—she did not know how he did it, but the bag was wedged between his legs and eased under the seat in front, and somehow this huge child made himself small for her. Tucked away. Almost decorous. The guy on the aisle had a newspaper, a big broadsheet, which he opened with a shake, but the child by the window gave her room. He did not smell, not even his hat. His eyes, when she checked, were shy and brown.
The bones of her back were pulled into the upholstery as the plane tilted and split from the runway, so she was travelling chest first, heart first, her pelvis cupped in the angle of the seat, and it was difficult—with gravity pulling her backward like this—to think of anything but getting up there. After a while, there was a bing-bong over the loudspeakers, but nothing changed and no one moved. The plane cut through a skein of dark-gray cloud, through a layer of liquid light, into another cloud that started as dark as steel wool, then thickened to gray and turned slowly white. In a moment, they would be free of it.
Pippa loved the moment of breaking out into the upper air, so blue and bright. She thought it would happen any second now, but the engines shifted and the plane started to bank and turn, and then turn again. They were still flying through whiteness, so there was no horizon to judge their angle by, but the three of them in the row were definitely canted over, once and then again. The man in the shiny suit dropped toward her shoulder, and the boy was pushed against the fuselage wall. His eyes—all their eyes—were drawn toward the window as the plane kept turning, not banking now so much as falling. The plane dropped and dropped. They fell from thick white through fog that was loose with unshed rain, until they were back out where they had started: the huge under-cloud dusk of earthbound weather. And now it was hard to tell if the plane was still turning, or if it was just falling. Another shift brought them to a steeper angle and to the idea that the nose was down: the plane might start to spiral through the air.
No one wanted to look at anyone else, because, if their eyes met, that would mean they were about to be killed. They could see the countryside below: a small city to one side, mountains directly beneath. The ground was approaching, though not very fast. It did not look dangerous, or even real, but she realized that it had been going on for a long time: this question of flying or falling. There was a sharp pain in her stomach, but her mind was completely clear. Her mind told her that she might die within the next sixty seconds or so. She had a leisurely amount of time to laugh at her fear and then to be afraid again, to consider last thoughts and blink them away: her husband and her three children asleep in their beds.
Crossword Puzzles with a Side of Millennial Socialism
It was a strangely buoyant sensation, this falling. The human beings in the plane were dropping at the same speed as the metal around them, so they were no longer forced against the fuselage. She understood the immense weight of the falling plane and the lightness of their bodies inside it.
They had hit a thermal, perhaps—or the opposite of a thermal—a gap in the mountain air. She looked for a lake below them, or some other feature that might make a chimney of cold they would tumble down, but there was nothing in the landscape that she could read in that way.
The boy in the window seat turned up to look at her, one hand lightly braced along the wall of the plane, the other holding on to the arm rest. And when she looked down at him—because he was almost directly below her now—she saw something she had not seen since her babies each opened their eyes for the first time. A full human being. Utterly himself. A new person in her life. And what use was that to her now?
He was seventeen, maybe eighteen. She was forty-three years old. In the lozenge of light that fell from the other side of the plane (which was now the top side), she saw that his eyes were not brown but amber. Sallow skin, black hair—his eyes were beautiful, but it was hard to tell if he was beautiful. Boys were a bit of a mystery to her. Despite the attention-seeking hat, he was not the object of anyone’s attention. He was—and, of course, this was what the hat was all about!—in disguise.
The boy was lurking inside this ridiculous hat, ironic and hidden. And, yes, he was terrified, but he was also shaking the woollen tassels, saying, “Really? Now?” And this helped her, quite a lot. She thought she might hold his hand. Or touch his hand, which was clenched around the tip of the arm rest; it looked white, as though fear had made him cold. She thought she could warm it out of him a little. The skin of his hand was right there.
But, sometime before the mountain tops—long before—at three thousand feet or five thousand feet, they came out of it, whatever it was. The plane levelled: their bodies grew heavy again as it started to climb. They turned in silence to the seats in front of them. Pippa resisted an urge to touch the gray plastic of the tray table. The boy pulled earbuds up from his green shirt pocket and she closed her eyes.
story_a:
The plane shuddered violently, a mechanical groan reverberating through the cabin as if the very airframe was crying out. Olivia clutched at the armrests, her knuckles whitening. Her breath came in short, clipped gasps, the oxygen mask that dangled uselessly above her head a mocking reminder of the fragility of human engineering. She looked around, seeking some kind of solace in the faces of her fellow passengers, but found only mirrors of her own fear.
It was then that her eyes fell upon the boy in the seat across the aisle. He couldn't have been more than fifteen, and he wore a hat so garish it seemed almost comical—a floppy, wide-brimmed thing with a pattern of neon green frogs. In any other circumstance, she might have laughed. But now, in this moment of suspended terror, it was the absurdity of the hat that made her pause, a fissure of normalcy in the surreal landscape of impending disaster.
Their eyes met, and for a heartbeat, the chaos around them receded. The boy's gaze was steady, his brown eyes wide but unblinking. There was a depth there, a maturity that belied his years, and Olivia felt an unexpected kinship, a shared acknowledgment of the gravity of their situation. She managed a weak smile, and to her astonishment, he smiled back, a fleeting curve of the lips that spoke of courage and resignation in equal measure.
The plane lurched again, a sickening drop that sent Olivia's stomach into her throat. She gripped the armrests tighter, her nails digging into the fabric. The boy's hat slipped sideways, and he reached up to adjust it with a calm that seemed almost surreal. His movements were deliberate, unhurried, as if he had all the time in the world. Olivia marveled at his composure, wondering what thoughts flickered behind those steady eyes.
She thought of her own son, Michael, who was roughly the same age. She had left him behind in New York, promising to be back in a week, to take him to his favorite comic book store. The memory of his hopeful face twisted her heart, a poignant reminder of all the unspoken promises that might now remain unfulfilled. She glanced at the boy again, a silent question in her eyes.
He seemed to understand. "I'm James," he said quietly, his voice barely audible over the din of the failing engines.
"Olivia," she replied, her voice trembling. She wanted to say more, to ask him about his family, his life, anything to anchor herself in the reality of human connection. But the words stuck in her throat, and all she could manage was a feeble, "Are you okay?"
James nodded, his expression inscrutable. "I think so." He paused, as if considering his next words carefully. "You?"
Olivia swallowed hard. "I'm not sure," she admitted, the honesty of her confession a small relief. "I have a son, you know. About your age."
James's eyes softened, a flicker of understanding passing between them. "I have a sister," he said. "She's younger. I promised to take her to the zoo next weekend."
Olivia felt a lump rise in her throat. "What kind of animals does she like?"
"Elephants," James said, a hint of a smile playing at the corners of his mouth. "She thinks they're magical."
Olivia nodded, a tear slipping down her cheek. "They are," she whispered. "They really are."
The plane shuddered again, a violent jolt that sent overhead compartments flying open, their contents spilling out in a chaotic avalanche. Olivia ducked instinctively, shielding her head with her arms. When she looked up, she saw that James had done the same, his ridiculous hat askew but still miraculously perched atop his head.
A strange calm settled over Olivia, a clarity that came from the realization that in these final moments, it was the small connections that mattered. The shared humanity, the fleeting smiles, the whispered confessions. She reached across the aisle, her fingers brushing against James's. He took her hand, his grip surprisingly strong, and they held on, a lifeline in the storm.
The lights flickered, then went out, plunging the cabin into darkness. Olivia could hear the frantic murmurs of the other passengers, the rising panic, but she focused on the warmth of James's hand, the steady rhythm of his breathing. She closed her eyes, conjuring the image of Michael's face, the way his eyes lit up when he talked about his favorite superheroes. She imagined the future she had promised him, the comic book store, the laughter, the love. She held onto that vision, a beacon in the night.
The plane began to level out, the violent turbulence easing into a smoother, albeit still precarious, descent. Olivia opened her eyes, her heart pounding. The emergency lights flickered on, casting an eerie glow over the cabin. She turned to James, his face illuminated in the dim light, and saw the same mixture of hope and fear reflected in his eyes.
"We might make it," she whispered, the words a fragile thread of hope.
James nodded, his grip on her hand tightening. "We will," he said, his voice steady. "We have to."
The plane continued its descent, the minutes stretching into an eternity. Olivia held her breath, her mind a whirl of fragmented thoughts and emotions. She thought of Michael, of James, of the promises made and the promises yet to be kept. She thought of the absurdity of the hat, a symbol of the resilience of the human spirit, the ability to find humor and hope even in the darkest of times.
And then, with a final shudder, the plane touched down, skidding along the runway before coming to a halt. A collective sigh of relief swept through the cabin, followed by the sounds of sobs and laughter, the cathartic release of emotions held in check for too long.
Olivia turned to James, their hands still clasped. "Thank you," she said, her voice choked with emotion.
James smiled, his eyes bright. "Thank you," he echoed.
As the emergency crews began to file in, Olivia and James remained seated, their hands intertwined. In that moment, they were no longer strangers, but survivors, bound by a shared experience that had forever changed them. They had faced the abyss and emerged, not unscathed, but stronger, their lives intertwined by a moment of connection in the midst of chaos.
And as they finally rose to disembark, Olivia glanced at the ridiculous hat one last time and felt a surge of gratitude for the unexpected bond it had symbolized—a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there is always light to be found in the connections we make.
story_b:
The plane shuddered, a metallic groan echoing through its belly as it danced with gravity in an unpredictable and relentless waltz. The cabin lights flickered, casting ghostly shadows that skipped across the faces of passengers, their expressions a tapestry of fear, resignation, and the occasional absurdity of denial. Amidst this symphony of chaos, she felt the world narrow, her vision tunneling until all that remained was the teenage boy across the aisle, his eyes wide beneath the brim of a hat so ridiculous it seemed to mock the very seriousness of their plight.
It was a hat that begged for attention—a beanie with long, drooping ears dyed in a cacophony of neon colors that shouldn't coexist. In another life, she might have smiled at its absurdity, but here, in the midst of their freefall, it became a beacon of life’s unpredictability, a reminder of how laughter and terror could sit side by side.
Her name was Mara, and she had spent her life in pursuit of balance, always striving for the controlled and the known. A series of meticulously planned choices—an orderly career, a sensible marriage that dissolved as quietly as it had begun, leaving behind no more than a slight crease in the fabric of her life. She had thought herself prepared for anything, but not for this—this tumbling through the sky, this confrontation with the sheer, chaotic force of existence.
The engines roared, a distant echo now, as if retreating from the immediacy of their collective dread. The air hummed with tension, a symphony of fear and hope, and Mara’s mind drifted, unmoored, back through the years. She saw herself at twenty, standing on the precipice of adulthood, armed with dreams that now seemed quaint and naive. She saw her mother’s face, lined with the wisdom of a thousand unspoken truths, and she wondered if she had ever really known her. Each memory was a choice, a fork in the road that had led inexorably to this moment, this spiraling descent into the unknown.
Mara’s gaze returned to the boy, his fingers gripping the armrests as though they were lifelines. There was something in his eyes—an echo of her own fear, yes, but also a spark of defiance, a refusal to be cowed. His hat seemed a testament to that spirit, a flag planted firmly in the ground of his identity. She imagined him selecting it in a store, perhaps as a joke or a dare, never knowing it would become a part of this shared moment, a fragment of their unexpected connection.
Her thoughts danced around the edges of regret, those small betrayals of self that had accumulated over time. She thought of the words unspoken, the risks not taken, the dreams deferred in the name of practicality. Her life was a series of choices, each leading here, and she wondered if this was the end or some strange new beginning. Was there a lesson in this plunge from the heavens, some revelation that could transform terror into understanding?
The boy, she realized, was looking at her with an intensity that belied his years, as if he too had found something in this shared gaze. What did he see, she wondered—a stranger, or someone who might understand the absurdity of this moment? She wanted to reach out, to offer some comfort or acknowledgment of their shared humanity, but the words stuck in her throat, swallowed by the roar of the world unraveling around them.
The cabin lights flickered again, and for a moment, the plane seemed to hang suspended, defying gravity’s pull. In that breath of stillness, Mara felt a strange calm settle over her, a quiet acceptance that was neither resignation nor defeat. It was as if the very act of staring into the boy’s eyes had tethered her to something larger than herself—a reminder that even in freefall, there was connection, a thread binding them to the earth and each other.
She thought of her mother again, her voice a whisper in the storm. "Life is what you make of it, Mara," she had said once, in one of those moments that seemed ordinary until it was recalled in times of need. "It’s not about the plans, it’s about the moments in between."
The plane tilted, another shudder passing through its frame, and Mara felt herself brace instinctively, muscles tensing against the inevitable. Yet her eyes never left the boy’s, and in them, she saw the reflection of her own courage mirrored back, a flicker of something unbreakable in the face of uncertainty.
She wanted to laugh, to tell him that his hat was ridiculous, that it was the most beautiful thing she had ever seen in this moment of freefall. She wanted to tell him that they were all ridiculous, each of them clinging to life’s absurdities in the face of its relentless unpredictability. But she said nothing, and perhaps that was enough.
As the plane continued its descent, Mara felt the world expand again, the cabin filling with the collective breath of those who shared this strange journey. The teenage boy with the ridiculous hat was just one thread in the tapestry, one connection among many, but he was there, and he was real. In the narrowing of existence, she had found something that felt like hope.
And as the ground rushed up to meet them, Mara understood that life was indeed about the moments in between—the glances, the absurdities, the unexpected connections that made up the fabric of their shared humanity. Whether this was the end or a beginning, she did not know. But as her eyes locked with the boy’s one last time, she felt ready to embrace whatever came next.

prompt: Trapped in a moment of freefall aboard a malfunctioning plane, a woman locks eyes with a teenage boy in a ridiculous hat, discovering an unexpected connection as they both brace for what might be their final moments.
ground_truth:
When she checked her boarding pass, she was in the middle of the row, and there was a man in a blue suit on the aisle, who gave her a big bleached-white smile as he stood to let her past. The window seat stayed unoccupied for a while, and her hopes rose when a man with a clipboard boarded the plane, his hair gauzy with dew. But there were still people in the aisle, and one of them now stopped beside her row: a huge boy, who was trying to make space for a rucksack in the overhead bin. His belly was right there—she could see it as his green shirt parted company with the belt of his jeans. The rucksack did not fit, so he clasped it to his chest as he turned sideways to squeeze past her and into the window seat. He was wearing a Peruvian hat in brown-and-white wool with a design of llamas and a flap over each ear, and there were tassels dangling from the flaps down to his collar line. A teen-ager. Ninety per cent muscle, thirty per cent puppy fat; he might have another few inches still to go. Once he was seated—she did not know how he did it, but the bag was wedged between his legs and eased under the seat in front, and somehow this huge child made himself small for her. Tucked away. Almost decorous. The guy on the aisle had a newspaper, a big broadsheet, which he opened with a shake, but the child by the window gave her room. He did not smell, not even his hat. His eyes, when she checked, were shy and brown.
The bones of her back were pulled into the upholstery as the plane tilted and split from the runway, so she was travelling chest first, heart first, her pelvis cupped in the angle of the seat, and it was difficult—with gravity pulling her backward like this—to think of anything but getting up there. After a while, there was a bing-bong over the loudspeakers, but nothing changed and no one moved. The plane cut through a skein of dark-gray cloud, through a layer of liquid light, into another cloud that started as dark as steel wool, then thickened to gray and turned slowly white. In a moment, they would be free of it.
Pippa loved the moment of breaking out into the upper air, so blue and bright. She thought it would happen any second now, but the engines shifted and the plane started to bank and turn, and then turn again. They were still flying through whiteness, so there was no horizon to judge their angle by, but the three of them in the row were definitely canted over, once and then again. The man in the shiny suit dropped toward her shoulder, and the boy was pushed against the fuselage wall. His eyes—all their eyes—were drawn toward the window as the plane kept turning, not banking now so much as falling. The plane dropped and dropped. They fell from thick white through fog that was loose with unshed rain, until they were back out where they had started: the huge under-cloud dusk of earthbound weather. And now it was hard to tell if the plane was still turning, or if it was just falling. Another shift brought them to a steeper angle and to the idea that the nose was down: the plane might start to spiral through the air.
No one wanted to look at anyone else, because, if their eyes met, that would mean they were about to be killed. They could see the countryside below: a small city to one side, mountains directly beneath. The ground was approaching, though not very fast. It did not look dangerous, or even real, but she realized that it had been going on for a long time: this question of flying or falling. There was a sharp pain in her stomach, but her mind was completely clear. Her mind told her that she might die within the next sixty seconds or so. She had a leisurely amount of time to laugh at her fear and then to be afraid again, to consider last thoughts and blink them away: her husband and her three children asleep in their beds.
Crossword Puzzles with a Side of Millennial Socialism
It was a strangely buoyant sensation, this falling. The human beings in the plane were dropping at the same speed as the metal around them, so they were no longer forced against the fuselage. She understood the immense weight of the falling plane and the lightness of their bodies inside it.
They had hit a thermal, perhaps—or the opposite of a thermal—a gap in the mountain air. She looked for a lake below them, or some other feature that might make a chimney of cold they would tumble down, but there was nothing in the landscape that she could read in that way.
The boy in the window seat turned up to look at her, one hand lightly braced along the wall of the plane, the other holding on to the arm rest. And when she looked down at him—because he was almost directly below her now—she saw something she had not seen since her babies each opened their eyes for the first time. A full human being. Utterly himself. A new person in her life. And what use was that to her now?
He was seventeen, maybe eighteen. She was forty-three years old. In the lozenge of light that fell from the other side of the plane (which was now the top side), she saw that his eyes were not brown but amber. Sallow skin, black hair—his eyes were beautiful, but it was hard to tell if he was beautiful. Boys were a bit of a mystery to her. Despite the attention-seeking hat, he was not the object of anyone’s attention. He was—and, of course, this was what the hat was all about!—in disguise.
The boy was lurking inside this ridiculous hat, ironic and hidden. And, yes, he was terrified, but he was also shaking the woollen tassels, saying, “Really? Now?” And this helped her, quite a lot. She thought she might hold his hand. Or touch his hand, which was clenched around the tip of the arm rest; it looked white, as though fear had made him cold. She thought she could warm it out of him a little. The skin of his hand was right there.
But, sometime before the mountain tops—long before—at three thousand feet or five thousand feet, they came out of it, whatever it was. The plane levelled: their bodies grew heavy again as it started to climb. They turned in silence to the seats in front of them. Pippa resisted an urge to touch the gray plastic of the tray table. The boy pulled earbuds up from his green shirt pocket and she closed her eyes.
